Reviews.Title: Excellent choice for small rooms
Reviews.Author: A. Bryant
Reviews.Content: Purchased this at a great price for my mother, and the TV has been perfect. Picture quality is high, particularly for a screen of this size. Predictably, the sound is a bit weak (you can easily amend this by hooking up speakers via the headphone jack, however). Philips is a solid brand - it's always worth it to pursue a reputable product - and the aesthetics of the TV are great; the design and build quality are fantastic.If you're searching for a nice HDTV for a bedroom or small room, this is among the best options.

Reviews.Title: Perfect for the kids' room
Reviews.Author: Mike IGC
Reviews.Content: Great TV.  Lightweight, easy to assemble the base, and hooked it up very quickly.  I'm not using a cable box, so I had to autoprogram the channels.  The picture looks great.  Extremely busy patterns appear to move and turn grainy even on an HD channel, but I've only seen that happen once.  Both HD and SD channels look fine - no complaints.Great feature: Channel list/skip.  Many of the channels are duplicates or they're in languages that we don't speak.  While in the channel skip menu, you can preview each channel as you run down the list.  My 32" TV from another brand doesn't have this feature.Sound: I continue to adjust the equalizer to try to get it to sound "normal".  It's not that bad once you lower the 2nd of the 5 EQ bands and fiddle around with the others.Since I'm running the cable directly in and have strange and out-of-order channels like 52.9, 66.20, 71.707, 74.641, 102.248, etc., I would have liked a "Favorite channel" feature or at least a manual channel labeler.  The remote is logically laid out and feels solid.Overall, I really do like the TV and have already recommended it to others.

Reviews.Title: Works Great So Far!
Reviews.Author: Lance
Reviews.Content: I have had this tv for about a week. I bought it for a home exercise room. Set up was easy. Even if you use basic cable it should pull in the HD channels. I know that Time Warner does. The only issue that I ran into is connecting my Roku box to it. You have to go through the second HDMI input and not the first. If you go through the second, the HDMI cable will carry the audio and video signals to the tv. I connected a DVD player and video player to it easily. I also suggest that if you have a spare set of computer speakers that you connect them through the headphone jack. The only issue is the tiny light at the botton which as one reviewer noted is extremely bright. I guess I will either get used to it or tape it over. Otherwise this was a great buy and an excellent choice for a small room or a children's bedroom.

Reviews.Title: Television
Reviews.Author: Linda Mabus
Reviews.Content: The television arrived as expected and was easy to setup and use.  We were looking for a small TV to use out in the gazabo and this one is perfect.

Reviews.Title: Philips 19PFL4505D/F7
Reviews.Author: ron j dio "ronald"
Reviews.Content: Very nice tv.  Good picture, excellant menu choices for set up preferences.  Speakers could be a little better, but they are fine.

Reviews.Title: I like it
Reviews.Author: Jorge Villegas Madri
Reviews.Content: This product fulfill my expectations.  It works fine and have an excellent resolution. Its size allows it to put in little spaces.

Reviews.Title: Good little tv!
Reviews.Author: traywilson
Reviews.Content: We've had this tv in our bedroom about a year now with no complaints. Picture quality is good, sound is a bit tinnish, easy to setup. Main thing I don't like about it is the self dimmer on this unit is very sensitive - constantly goes dim, bright, dim, bright - esp. when watching in a dark room.

Reviews.Title: My extra computer monitor
Reviews.Author: charles k major
Reviews.Content: Needing an extra monjtor because of restricted space I decided on this HDTV.It was a good choice. The Tv works great as a monitor, is a cinch to set up. and a pleasure to use. Thanks Philips!

Reviews.Title: Disappointed
Reviews.Author: J C Holzschuh
Reviews.Content: Normally I like Phillips equipment but this TV set had problems.It has a feature which brightens the picture in bright rooms and dims it so it isn't blinding in a dark room.. Good idea gone wrong. The picture would brighten and dim randomly and often. Gave me a headache. Back to Samsung.

Reviews.Title: Decent TV
Reviews.Author: llamaofthesea
Reviews.Content: Decent enough replacement for the Sony Trinitron CRT TV we had in our bedroom, which had a cracked case and was taking up too much room.  I like the smaller footprint of this TV, but when watching SD TV, the picture honestly looked better on the old 4:3 Trinitron.  I picked up this TV for much less than the ~$198 price on Amazon and am glad I didn't pay that much for it.  Pretty middle of the road in my opinion - No real stand-out qualities, but also no fatal flaws.**Pros*** Smaller footprint/lighter than a CRT* 2 HDMI inputs* VGA input for using as a computer monitor* Basic - Not overwhelming with options/functions.**Cons*** Like many smaller flatscreen TVs, this has small speakers that aren't front-facing.* Composite jack (Red-White-Yellow) is on the side, making the cables for older connections visible.* Bright white power light (located directly under the "PHILIPS" text on the front of the display) makes it seem like someone is shining a flashlight at you.  Easy enough to cover up though, so this is a minor complaint.Finally, just because I had a hard time finding this info...If you have Dish Network, I used code "651" to pair this with my 6.0 IR/UHF Pro remote (listed on the back of the Dish Network remote). To pair this TV to that remote, hold the TV button on the upper left of Dish Network remote until the top 4 buttons light up, then press 6+5+1 then #.  The TV button should flash 3 times, after which you can control the TV's power and volume from your Dish remote.  If the 651 code didn't work for you, here are the other suggested codes that I found for pairing that remote to Philips-brand TVs: 525, 566, 651, 652, 655, 656, 671, 690, 723, 724, 729.  Hope that helps someone.

Reviews.Title: Great little TV
Reviews.Author: S. Dill "CincySteve"
Reviews.Content: This is an overall decent 19" TV.  Looks great in our kitchen!  Picture is crisp and clear.ProsGreat PictureEasy SetupLow Profile for wall mountingGreat glossy lookCons-The TV is lacking in sound quality.  Unfortunatly, you arn't going to find ANY 19" with great sound so this TV compares at middle of the road.  The Vizio 19" is an exception but not great for wall mounting.  This TV is acceptable for our application.-Changing channels can be frusterating because there is about a 1-2 second delay from when you change the station to when the picture actually appears.  Not a huge deal but a little annoying when trying to find something on.-Can't label the stations.  Annoying when you can't remember what station is what number.

Reviews.Title: Flat screen TV
Reviews.Author: Yar
Reviews.Content: For the most part I am satisified with the TV. The sound leaves a lot to be desired. It take a while to come on when you turn it on. Other than that I like it.

Reviews.Title: Bad Choice
Reviews.Author: Jeter
Reviews.Content: As I started the install the TV froze and would not continue.  Started over, same deal.  Called tech support and they said it's bad to send it back, which I did.

Reviews.Title: Incompatible with VCR's
Reviews.Author: Robert A. Gilliam
Reviews.Content: I'm returning this TV because it can't display the composite output of my Sony VCR properly. The picture jumps up and down slightly, or it jumps back and forth between full and half its vertical resolution. It seems like this TV can't align the separate interlaced parts of the NTSC signal properly. No manual adjustment makes any difference. It happens even with newly recorded material. My VCR works perfectly with two different CRT TV's, so there's nothing wrong with my VCR. The TV's composite input works fine with my satellite TV receiver and my digital camera. Don't buy this TV if you want to use it with a VCR.According to the DDC info the TV sent to my computer, this TV supports up to 1920x1080 signals at 60Hz. But I couldn't get it to display analog VGA signals higher than 1360x768. (Its native resolution is 1366x768.) This shouldn't be a problem unless you want to do a multi-monitor set-up and your video card can't run different monitors at different resolutions.I had no reception problems with digital broadcast TV as long as my rabbit ears were aligned properly for the station. I'm just outside a major city, though.Like all LCD displays, the black isn't as dark as a good CRT. This TV's black is lighter than my ViewSonic 24" LCD computer monitor.The TV has a power-saving backlight feature. It causes annoying brightness fluctuations with my VCR's playback on both composite and RF inputs, but it can be turned off. There's no other way to dim the backlight, though. The brightness adjustment doesn't change the backlight.A quarter inch around the edge of the screen is brighter than the rest of the screen when displaying black. I understand this is due to the edge lighting and is common on LCD TV's. It isn't normally noticeable.You can mask channels so you won't see them while channel-surfing. (There are lots of religious and Spanish channels on digital TV.)The zoom setting perfectly corrects letterboxed 4:3 content. The 16:9 setting corrects some broadcasts that are clearly at the wrong aspect ratio (squished).The speakers have very poor bass, but that's to be expected with a TV this size. The TV has a headphones connection so you can easily hook it up to an audio amp and big speakers. There's also a digital audio output. Listening to digital TV on my high-quality headphones, the audio quality is mediocre. Even with the TV's equalizer adjusted, both the bass and high end are weak compared to a CD player or computer.The power light on the front is white and very bright. If I kept this TV, I'd definitely put a piece of tape over it.For the 6 people who care, it works perfectly with my antique Atari 800 computer which outputs an RF NTSC signal on channel 2 or 3. (Joust was a great game.)The manual is available in PDF format at the Philips Web site.I would've been happy with this TV if it weren't for the incompatibility with VCR's.Update: I've decided to keep the TV because I realized that I could use an old VCR to convert the composite signal to NTSC RF which this TV displays correctly. There are also converters available for under US$20. Search for "RF modulator." This is a better option than returning the TV.Update: There seems to be a problem with the red/green/blue balance. A sea green color looks blue. Adjusting the tint to correct it makes the flesh tones wrong. I had this problem with a CRT and was able to fix it by adjusting the RGB dials inside the TV. There's no RGB adjustment in the menus of this TV, only tint which is insufficient. It's not a big deal to me, but if you're a stickler for color accuracy....
